description: a(n) = smallest number k such that k^n is the sum of n positive n-th powers, or 0 if no solution exists.
references: N. J. A. Sloane and Simon Plouffe, The Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences, Academic Press, 1995 (includes this sequence).
D. Wells, The Penguin Dictionary of Curious and Interesting Numbers. Penguin Books, NY, 1986, 164.
prog: (PARI) A007666(n,s,m,p=n)={ /* Check whether s can be written as sum of n positive p-th powers not larger than m^p. If so, return the base a of the largest term a^p.*/ s>n*m^p && return; n==1&&return(ispower(s,p,&n)*n); /* if s,m,p are not given, s>=n and m are arbitrary and p=n. */ !s&&for(m=round(sqrtn(n,n)),9e9,A007666(n,m^n,m-1,n)&&return(m)); for(a=ceil(sqrtn(s\n,p)),min(sqrtn(s-n+1,p),m),A007666(n-1,s-a^p,a,p)&&return(a));} \\ _M. F. Hasler_, Nov 17 2015
crossrefs: k^n = T(n, 1)^n + ... + T(n, n)^n, where T() is given in A061988.
Examples for n=4 are in A003294.
Examples for n=5 are in A063922.
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, _Robert G. Wilson v_
extensions: The next term a(6) has been claimed to be 1141, but this is incorrect. In fact, 1141^6 is the sum of seven 6th powers. - _Jud McCranie_, Jun 10 2007
a(6) is either 0 (no solution) or greater than 272580 (see above link to resta.htm page). - _Jon E. Schoenfield_, Jun 10 2007
